Award.AwardTitle: Measuring the Mass Flux and Magnetic Evolution of Jets in the Solar Atmosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposing team will carry out a comprehensive study of the structure and evolution of coronal hole jets in order to discover the connections between the solar wind and magnetic structures at the solar surface. The team will use data from instruments on board the Hinode spacecraft to measure the parameters relevant to the magnetic evolution that leads to explosive events (EEs) and coronal hole jets (CHJs) on the Sun, as well as to measure the mass that is ejected from such events. Explosive events and coronal hole jets are particularly well suited to the spectroscopic analysis and magnetic field studies that this team will perform. The team specifically intends to study how the Sun's magnetic field evolution triggers EEs and CHJs, to determine how often EEs promote a measurable response in the solar chromosphere and/or corona, and to calculate the total mass flux of CHJs. This research will increase our understanding of the variable flow of mass and energy through the lower solar atmosphere.

The comprehensive statistics for CHJs collected by this team will provide insight into the possible role of these jets in the mass and energy flux going into the corona and solar wind, and thus aid in the development of improved predictive space weather models that depend on coupling the lower solar atmosphere to the corona. The team will provide a database of all analyzed CHJ events to the public, so that the scientific results of this investigation can be further exploited by the general solar physics community. The co-investigator of this effort is a female scientist employed in industry, so this project will advance the participation of underrepresented groups in science while enhancing an ongoing academic-federal lab-industrial partnership.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Sun's atmosphere regularly produces short-lived geyser-like structures that we call coronal jets [IMAGE 1]. They are shot upwards from the Sun's surface at speeds of around 1 million miles per hour and can extend up to 50,000 miles (six times the diameter of the Earth). The jets typically last 10 to 20 minutes and, like geysers, they can repeat in the same location on the Sun

The jets release hot gas at a temperature of 1 million degrees into the Sun's atmosphere, and provide a dynamic contribution to the solar wind -- a stream of high energy particles that impacts the Earth.

The presence of hot, million degree gas in the Sun's atmosphere has long been a puzzle to scientists, but the energy source is generally believed to lie with the Sun's magnetic field. A coronal jet is one of the best examples in which we see magnetic energy converted rapidly to heating and motion of the gas.

Dr Peter Young (George Mason University and NASA Goddard Space Flight Center) led a NSF project to measure many coronal jets using instruments on board the Hinode and Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO) spacecraft. By observing jets with a special instrument called EIS (Extreme ultraviolet Imaging Spectrometer), the team was able to accurately measure the amount of hot gas produced by the jets, and find out how fast the gas is accelerated and to what temperature.

By also using the Helioseismic and Magnetic Imager on board SDO, the team was able to determine that the jets were driven by the destruction of magnetic field elements - a clear indicator that the jets are caused by the magnetic field.

A surprise for Dr Young was the discovery of a class of jets that were invisible in solar images, but were revealed in special "speed maps" obtained with EIS. These maps show when gas is moving towards or away from us. Almost half of the jets found in these speed maps turned out to be invisible when looking at normal images, and so Dr Young called them "dark jets". [An example is shown in IMAGE 2.]

The dark jets show that, in addition to the spectacular jets that light up the Sun's atmosphere, the Sun also quietly releases small amounts of hot gas that had not been detected before.
